name: Historic Honolulu → Waikīkī → Diamond Head View
description: Monarchy + courts + coral church → beach legend → park vibes → iconic crater. A greatest-hits mixtape.

stops.title: ʻIolani Palace

cheapEats.budgetHint: Snack now, feast later. Your itinerary doesn’t need to be dramatic.

funFacts: Only royal palace on U.S. soil.
Early adopter of electric lighting in the 1800s.

stops.title: Aliʻiōlani Hale & King Kamehameha Statue

cheapEats.budgetHint: If you see a lunch special, that’s your sign from the universe.

funFacts: Name means “house of heavenly kings.”
Long tied to Hawaiʻi’s courts.

stops.title: Kawaiahaʻo Church

cheapEats.budgetHint: A pastry is valid cultural research.

funFacts: Often nicknamed ‘Hawaiʻi’s Westminster Abbey’.
Built from thousands of coral slabs.

stops.title: Duke Kahanamoku Statue (Kūhiō Beach)

cheapEats.budgetHint: Shave ice counts as hydration. Don’t @ me.

funFacts: Olympic swimming champion.
Helped popularize surfing worldwide.

stops.title: Kapiʻolani Park

cheapEats.budgetHint: Your wallet loves a picnic. Your knees love shade.

funFacts: Dedicated in 1877.
Named for Queen Kapiʻolani.

stops.title: Lēʻahi (Diamond Head) Viewpoint

cheapEats.budgetHint: Earn your noodles. You did great.

funFacts: Tuff cone from explosive eruptions.
‘Diamond’ name came from mistaken crystals.

name: North Shore: Haleʻiwa Stories & Surf
description: Food trucks, river turtles, surf legends, and the chillest pace your nervous system has ever met.

stops.title: Haleʻiwa Town Center

cheapEats.budgetHint: Pick one hero item or accept the nap.

funFacts: North Shore swells peak in winter.

stops.title: Haleʻiwa Aliʻi Beach Park

nearby: Picnic with your food truck plate
cheapEats.budgetHint: ‘Food + ocean view’ with zero cover charge.

funFacts: Great surf watching in season.

stops.title: Anahulu River Bridge

nearby: Iced coffee / fresh juice in town
cheapEats.budgetHint: Hydration = performance.

funFacts: You may spot honu (sea turtles).

stops.title: Sunset Beach (Viewpoint Stop)

nearby: Simple snacks or plate lunch nearby
cheapEats.budgetHint: If you find a hearty meal under $15, take the W.

funFacts: Winter swells can be huge offshore.

name: Windward: Kailua → Lanikai (Optional Pillboxes)
description: Breezy beaches, local town energy, optional WWII viewpoints, and maximum ‘I live here now’ feelings.

stops.title: Kailua Town

cheapEats.budgetHint: Start snacky. Beach decisions are emotional.

funFacts: Trade winds = breezy vibes.

stops.title: Kailua Beach Park

cheapEats.budgetHint: Bring water + snacks. Future-you will be smug.

funFacts: Frequently ranked among top beaches.

stops.title: Lanikai Pillboxes (Optional Viewpoint)

cheapEats.budgetHint: No vendors up here. Pack snacks like a responsible legend.

funFacts: WWII-era observation structures.

stops.title: Lanikai Beach

cheapEats.budgetHint: Keep it simple: water + snack + respectful vibes.

funFacts: Views toward the Mokulua Islands (“the Mokes”).

name: Pearl Harbor & ʻEwa Reflections
description: A respectful, story-forward walk with space to breathe afterward (plus a low-key comfort-food stop).

stops.title: Pearl Harbor Visitor Area

cheapEats.budgetHint: This is a ‘quiet mind’ stop. Food can wait 20 minutes.

funFacts: Pearl Harbor is also called Puʻuloa.

stops.title: USS Arizona Memorial Area

cheapEats.budgetHint: If you need a moment, take it. That’s the right move.

funFacts: Many visitors describe a quiet stillness here.

stops.title: ʻEwa Comfort-Food Reset Stop

cheapEats.budgetHint: Comfort food is not ‘unserious.’ It’s how humans recover.

funFacts: Local comfort foods reflect many cultures.

name: Downtown Toronto: Old Town → Waterfront
description: Foundations, power, rebellion, skyline, and lake breeze.

cheapEats.budgetHint: One sandwich can be a full meal.
Eat after.
Daytime is cheaper.
Lake views are free.

name: Sultanahmet: Empires in 3 Hours
description: A greatest-hits walk through Istanbul’s iconic old city—Byzantine, Ottoman, and everything in between.

stops.title: Hippodrome & Obelisks

nearby: Simit + ayran from a street vendor
cheapEats.budgetHint: Snacks are strategy. Your future self will thank you.

funFacts: This was the stadium of Constantinople—chariot races, riots, and royal drama.
Several monuments here were moved from across the ancient world.

stops.title: German Fountain
funFacts: Built in Germany, shipped in pieces, assembled here in 1900.
Look up: the dome’s interior glints with gold mosaics.

stops.title: Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmed Mosque)

cheapEats.budgetHint: Hydrate like a pro. Istanbul walking is an extreme sport.

funFacts: It’s famous for its interior blue İznik tiles.
Built in the early 1600s, it was a statement of imperial confidence.

stops.title: Hagia Sophia
funFacts: For nearly 1,000 years it was the largest cathedral in the world.
Its dome inspired centuries of architecture around the region.

stops.title: Basilica Cistern
funFacts: An underground water reservoir supported by rows of columns.
Keep an eye out for the Medusa-head stone blocks.

stops.title: Topkapı Palace First Courtyard

nearby: Tea in the palace gardens area
cheapEats.budgetHint: A tea break is not quitting—it’s tactical recharging.

funFacts: This was the center of Ottoman power for centuries.
Palace life ran on protocol, secrecy, and dazzling craft.

stops.title: Gülhane Park

nearby: Tea + simit in the park cafes
cheapEats.budgetHint: Sit. Sip. Pretend you’re in a historical drama montage.

funFacts: One of Istanbul’s oldest public parks.
It sits on land that once belonged to the palace grounds.

stops.title: Arasta Bazaar & Mosaic Museum Area

nearby: Çay (tea) in a tiny shop courtyard
cheapEats.budgetHint: Browse first, buy last. Your bargaining game improves with confidence.

funFacts: A smaller, calmer alternative to the Grand Bazaar.
The Great Palace Mosaic Museum is nearby inside the bazaar area.

stops.title: Little Hagia Sophia

nearby: Lentil soup (mercimek) at a neighborhood lokanta
cheapEats.budgetHint: This is your ‘locals’ corner’—simple food, big comfort.

funFacts: Originally a 6th‑century Byzantine church of Saints Sergius and Bacchus.
Often described as a ‘prototype’ for the Hagia Sophia’s dome ideas.

name: Bazaars & Domes: Eminönü to Grand Bazaar
description: Spices, tiles, skyline domes, and the city’s most famous markets—classic Istanbul street energy.

stops.title: Eminönü Square

nearby: Balık ekmek (fish sandwich) by the water
cheapEats.budgetHint: Eat where locals line up. That’s your best map.

funFacts: This is a major ferry hub—people-watching is elite here.
You’re at the edge of the Golden Horn and the old city.

stops.title: New Mosque (Yeni Cami)
funFacts: Its courtyard feels like a pause button amid the market rush.
It anchors the waterfront skyline near the bazaar district.

stops.title: Spice Bazaar (Mısır Çarşısı)

nearby: Turkish delight samples (yes, count them as calories)
Pick up dried fruit/nuts for the walk
cheapEats.budgetHint: Buy a small mix, not a giant bag. Your luggage has feelings.

funFacts: Known for spices, teas, sweets, and fragrant chaos.
Even if you buy nothing, the smells are the souvenir.

stops.title: Rüstem Pasha Mosque
funFacts: Famous for vivid İznik tiles.
Tucked above market streets—like a secret level.

stops.title: Galata Bridge Viewpoint

cheapEats.budgetHint: Split one sandwich. Save room for later snacks.

funFacts: Fishermen often line the railings.
One side looks to the historic peninsula; the other to Galata and Beyoğlu.

stops.title: Süleymaniye Mosque & Courtyard

nearby: Simple lokanta meals in the surrounding streets
cheapEats.budgetHint: Order soup + one main. Istanbul portions are generous.

funFacts: Designed by Mimar Sinan for Süleiman the Magnificent.
The terraces offer some of the best skyline views.

stops.title: Şehzade Mosque
funFacts: Commissioned by Süleiman as a memorial to his son.
Often called one of Sinan’s early masterpieces.

stops.title: Grand Bazaar (Kapalıçarşı)

nearby: Çay in a tiny shop (often offered)
cheapEats.budgetHint: Accept tea if offered—just don’t feel obligated to buy.

funFacts: One of the world’s oldest and largest covered markets.
It’s basically a city inside a city.

stops.title: Nuruosmaniye Mosque (Bazaar Gate)
funFacts: Notable Ottoman Baroque style—different vibe from earlier domes.
Sits right by a major entrance to the Grand Bazaar.

name: Galata & Beyoğlu: Towers, Tram Bells, and Street Life
description: From waterfront Karaköy up to Galata Tower, then along İstiklal to Taksim—cafés, culture, and big-city Istanbul.

stops.title: Karaköy Waterfront

cheapEats.budgetHint: Breakfast counts as sightseeing if you eat it outside with a view.

funFacts: Karaköy is a historic port district that’s become a café-and-gallery hotspot.
You’re at the foot of the hill leading up to Galata and Beyoğlu.

stops.title: Galata Bridge (Under-bridge Energy)

cheapEats.budgetHint: Eat one thing, keep walking. This tour is cardio-with-benefits.

funFacts: The bridge is famous for fishermen above and eateries below.
It links the old city vibes with the newer Galata side.

stops.title: Galata Tower
funFacts: Originally a medieval Genoese tower (14th century).
Its viewpoint is one of the city’s classics.

stops.title: Tünel Square & Historic Funicular
funFacts: The Tünel (1875) is among the world’s oldest underground urban railways.
It solves a problem: this hill is steep.

stops.title: Pera Museum Area

nearby: Turkish coffee in a side-street café
cheapEats.budgetHint: Coffee here is a ritual. Give it five calm minutes.

funFacts: Pera was historically the ‘European’ quarter of the city.
This area is packed with galleries, cafés, and old passageways.

stops.title: Çiçek Pasajı (Flower Passage)

nearby: Quick roasted nuts from vendors outside
cheapEats.budgetHint: If you sit, share plates. Your wallet will breathe easier.

funFacts: A historic arcade passage with restaurants and a lively atmosphere.
One of İstiklal’s most recognizable interior ‘streets’.

stops.title: St. Antoine Church
funFacts: A landmark Catholic church on bustling İstiklal.
Step inside for a quiet reset.

stops.title: Taksim Square

cheapEats.budgetHint: Hydrate now. Your feet have unionized.

funFacts: Often called the heart of modern Istanbul.
A major transport and gathering point.

stops.title: Gezi Park (Cool-down)
funFacts: One of the last green pockets in central Beyoğlu.
A small park with a big place in recent history.

name: Fener & Balat: Colorful Streets on the Golden Horn
description: A slower, neighborhood-forward walk: viewpoints, courtyards, colorful stair streets, and layers of community history.

stops.title: Golden Horn Waterfront Start

cheapEats.budgetHint: Start with tea. This tour is meant to be un-rushed.

funFacts: The Golden Horn is a natural harbor that shaped Istanbul’s growth.
Neighborhood life here feels different from the big-ticket center.

stops.title: Ecumenical Patriarchate (Phanar)
funFacts: A historic center of Eastern Orthodox Christianity.
The area is also known as Phanar (Fener).

stops.title: Fener Greek Orthodox College (Red School)
funFacts: Famous for its striking red-brick façade.
One of the neighborhood’s most photographed landmarks.

stops.title: Balat Colorful Streets

cheapEats.budgetHint: This is the ‘small café’ zone—one drink buys you a perfect rest.

funFacts: Balat is known for colorful houses, cafés, and layered community history.
It’s best enjoyed slowly—watch for cats, murals, and tiny courtyards.

stops.title: Merdivenli Yokuş Steps View
funFacts: A classic photo spot: steep steps framed by bright buildings.
The real charm is the everyday life around it.

stops.title: Chora Church (Kariye)
funFacts: Renowned for extraordinary Byzantine mosaics and frescoes.
A bit farther out—worth it if you love art and quiet.

stops.title: Neighborhood Tea & Coffee Stop

cheapEats.budgetHint: Order one drink, share one sweet. Perfect Istanbul math.

funFacts: In Istanbul, tea breaks are part of the itinerary—always.
Neighborhood cafés are where the city feels most ‘real.’

stops.title: Golden Horn Viewpoint Finish
funFacts: The Golden Horn curves like a comma between neighborhoods.
Sunset here can be unreal on a clear day.

name: Downtown Heartbeat: Gold, Coffee & Street Life
description: A tight downtown loop: plaza → theater → market → parks → pedestrian pulse. San José’s everyday heartbeat.

stops.title: Plaza de la Cultura (Orientation)

cheapEats.budgetHint: Hydrate, snack, keep it light—you’ve got stories ahead.

funFacts: This stop is part of San José’s walkable core—short distances, big stories.
Locals use these spaces daily, not just for sightseeing.

cheapEats.budgetHint: Hydrate, snack, keep it light—you’ve got stories ahead.

Locals use these spaces daily, not just for sightseeing.
